Advanced Methods for LiDAR and Photogram.1: 2 Multi-View Matching In many tasks it is often required to find matches across multiple views and recent studies have suggested that jointly optimizing the correspondences across the whole set can lead to significant improvements when compared to computing matches between pairs of views in isolation [124, 166], since pairwise matching algorithms can generate noisy and unreliable results.
Advanced Methods for LiDAR and Photogram.2: It is shown in some recent works [124, 78, 166] that, if all the pairwise correspondences are collected in a block-matrix, then cycle consistency can be reduced to the requirement that such a matrix is positive semidefinite and low-rank.
Advanced Methods for LiDAR and Photogram.3: In [166] the joint matching problem is formulated as a low-rank matrix recovery task and the nuclear-norm relaxation for rank minimization is employed.

Synchronization Problems in Computer Vis.ref_texts: [205] X. Zhou, M. Zhu, and K. Daniilidis. Multi-image matching via fast alternating minimization. In Proceedings of the International Conference on Computer Vision , pages 4032 – 4040, 2015.
Synchronization Problems in Computer Vis.1: Permutation synchronization finds application in multi-view matching [47, 205], where nodes are images and objects are features.
Synchronization Problems in Computer Vis.2: Moreover, recent studies have suggested that jointly optimizing the correspondences across the whole dataset can lead to significant improvements when compared to computing matches between pairs of views in isolation [143, 205], since pairwise matching algorithms can generate noisy and unreliable results.
Synchronization Problems in Computer Vis.3: A different approach is adopted in [92, 47, 205, 127, 143, 164, 197] where multiview matching is solved in two steps, as shown in Figure 4.
Synchronization Problems in Computer Vis.4: In [205] the joint matching problem is formulated as a lowrank matrix recovery task and the nuclear-norm relaxation for rank minimization is employed, whereas in [127] a practical and efficient method is proposed based on spectral decomposition and an approximate strategy for projection onto ISym(d).
Synchronization Problems in Computer Vis.5: Note that the methods in [92, 47, 205, 127] do not solve a synchronization problem, since they compute relative permutations instead of absolute ones.
